Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative RUI. Nonlinear Schroedinger Models in Fluid Dynamics: Rogue Waves and Vortex Filaments
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project combines the complementary expertise of the two principal investigators (PIs) to study two areas of fluid dynamics modeled by the integrable focusing Nonlinear Schroedinger (NLS) equation and higher order generalizations: rogue wave generation in deep water, and vortex filament dynamics, for which accurate numerical methods will be used to guide theoretical work, and to study more physically relevant models. Floquet theory, dynamical systems methods, perturbation theory, numerical spectral diagnostics, and multi-symplectic and conformal integrators, will be used to address the questions of generation and persistence of rogue waves. Physical lab-tank experiments will test and validate the analysis of the correlation between proximity to instabilities and homoclinic data, and the likelihood of rogue waves; whether nonlinear damping eliminates rogue waves through downshifting. Stability and dynamics of vortex filaments will be investigated theoretically and numerically.

Rogue waves are extremely rare and destructive waves in the ocean that are believed to arise spontaneously (in contrast with tsunamis). They are transient large amplitude waves whose heights are significantly larger than the background sea, 25 meters and up to 35 meters. The research on rogue waves is aimed at improving predictors of these extreme wave events. Vortex ﬁlaments are important models of localized vorticity structures that often emerge as distinctive features in various physical phenomena; for example, vortex ﬁlaments can be used to describe the ﬂow of superﬂuids and of turbulent ﬂuids. Filamentary structures in geophysical systems (e.g. tornados) and in magneto-hydrodynamics (e.g. slender plasma-ﬁlled tubes in the solar corona) can also be modeled by vortex ﬁlaments. The analytical and numerical tools developed for both rogue wave and vortex filament models will be of value for other applied fluid mechanical problems.
This research will involve one undergraduate and one graduate student at each of the institutions. The PIs will continue mentoring students from underrepresented groups and broadening their training by bringing students to meetings that connect mathematicians and experimentalists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project deals with two different phenomena surprisingly governed by the same mathematical model: the motion of vortex filaments in ideal fluids, such as smoke rings in the air, and the formation of rogue waves in the ocean—steep, high-amplitude, localized waves that appear and disappear suddenly, even in calm waters. 

 The mathematical equation that describes both is the focusing nonlinear Schrödinger equation, a canonical model in which dispersion and nonlinearity can combine to amplify small disturbances in a base state, leading to growth of instabilities. 

One of the underlying themes of this project is the study of stability of certain solutions of the model. For vortex filaments, the focus has been on determining whether special knotted filaments (some of these realized experimentally for the first time only in recent years) persist or are destroyed by small changes in initial conditions, or physically realistic perturbations of the model equations (to account, for example, for the thickness of the filament or the presence of an axial flow).  In the context of rogue waves, determining the stability of solutions that possess key features of rogue waves leads to effective criteria for identifying good candidates for physical relevant descriptions of rogue waves.

 The solution space of the nonlinear Schrödinger equation has a rich geometric structure. As a consequence, the effect of instabilities of an unstable base state can be described explicitly in terms of exact formulas for its homoclinic orbits. These are solutions that rise above the base state and then subside back to it, and accurately capture the development of instabilities. Homoclinic orbits, for example, describe how vortex filaments starting near an unstable filament will behave at the onset of instability, often displaying large changes in their topology (e.g. undergoing knotting and unknotting). Homoclinic orbits of unstable background sea states are also used to model one of the main mechanism of rogue wave formation (modulational instability and nonlinear focusing): just like physical rogue waves, their steep peaks develop and then subside in a short time. 

 In the latter context, a significant outcome of this project is that proximity to homoclinic orbits can be related to increased rogue wave generation, even in the case of rogue waves emerging from more realistic sea states (the so-called JONSWAP rogue waves). This result has led to a diagnostic tool which, by converting numerical or field data to spectral representations of solutions of the nonlinear Schrödinger equation, predicts the likelihood of rogue wave occurrence in a given spatial region. This tool could be developed into a real-time warning system for ocean navigation, to help ships minimize chances of encountering these destructive waves.
